results.title: Rashomon = In the woods
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa, Jinkichi Minoura and Daiei Motion Picture Company
results.brief_description: A woodcutter (Takashi Shimura) witnesses a horrific series of events: A noble man (Mayasuki Mori) and his wife (Machiko Kyo) are ambushed by the famous bandit Tajomaru (Toshiro Mifune). The wife is raped and the nobleman is killed in a duel. Tajomaru is arrested and tried. In the telling of the tale in front of the judge, however, each of the four participants - the bandit, the wife, the woodcutter, the ghost of the murdered nobleman - gives a different view of what actually happened. Is any of them telling the truth? Akira Kurosawa leaves us to ponder the subjective nature of Truth. In this work he borrows heavily from Japan’s artistic tradition, specially kabuki theatre, where events are often repeated with slight variations. Winner of Golden Lion, Venice, 1951. Adapted from two original stories by Ryunosuke Akugatawa (“Rashomon” and “In a grove”).

results.title: Raymonda
results.creator_credit: Shuji Fujii, Takeshi Hara, Primetime, RPTA, Bolshoi Theatre of the USSR, Videofilm and NHK Entapuraizu
results.brief_description: The Bolshoi Theatre Ballet performs Raymonda at the Bolshoi Theatre, music by Aleksandr Glazunov, scenario by Lydia Pashkova and Marius Petipa with original choreography by Marius Petipa and Aleksandr Gorsky, revised by Yuri Grigorovich. Raymonda (Natalya Bessmertnova) is to marry Jean de Brienne (Yuri Vasyuchenko), but the Saraceb knight, Abderakhman (Gediminas Taranda), forces his attention on her while her betrothed is on a crusade. At the last moment Jean returns, fights his rival and wins the hand of Raymonda. With a spectacular stage setting and costume design, powerful performances by the principal dancers, and the magical sound of the music of the Bolshoi Theatre Orchestra conducted by Algis Zhuraitis.

results.title: Raymond Klibansky: from philosophy to life
results.creator_credit: Anne-Marie Tougas, Yves Bisaillon, Tele-Quebec and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This beautifully filmed portrayal of German Jewish philosopher Raymond Klibansky by director Anne-Marie Tougas resulted from a meeting Tougas had with the great philosopher and the profound effect Klibansky had on her during that meeting. Inspired by Klibansky, Tougas has written a script, poetic in tone and atmospheric in mood, which transforms this documentary into a thoughtful and at moments, even sensual, piece of work. Born in 1905, Klibansky has spanned a century of change, of war, oppression, upheaval, peace and liberation. A historian and philosopher, he is also a political activist and a strong believer in humanism and tolerance. Between World War I and II, he moved to Heidelberg, Germany, a vibrant and intellectual city where, as a professor at Heidelberg University, he mixed with the academia, sociologists and other philosophers. With the rise of Hitler and nazism Klibansky went into exile in England where he became Chief Intelligence Officer in the British Secret Service during World War II. In 1946 he finally moved to Montreal where he has continued to promote tolerance and fight for freedom on all fronts. Klibansky discusses his life, analyses his philosophy and its relationship to world events and humanity and provides perhaps a different slant on world history during the 20th century. Included in the documentary are stills, photographs, archival newsreel footage and interviews with Sonja Sutton-Steiniger (Klibansky’s sister), Ethel Groffier (his wife), Georges Leroux (philosopher and friend), Rainer Maria Lepsius (sociologist), Jana Patocka (daughter of philosopher Jan Patocka) among others. Voice and narration by Claudio Besso in English with some interviews in French with English subtitles.

results.title: Raptures : an underwater odyssey
results.creator_credit: Lucy Trippett, David Hannan and David Hannan Productions
results.brief_description: David Hannan and his team have travelled to new locations to films this sequel to the fantastic “Coral Sea dreaming”. This extroadinary musical documentary is the culmination of 7 years filming in Micronesia, the Indian Ocean, the Coral Sea and the Great Barrier Reef. Stunning new cinematic techniques deliver vision of exceptional quality complemented by a musical score composed by Vance Burrow. This is an intoxicating musical journey capturing the beauty and diversity of our fragile ocean realm which can be used as a tool for stress release and meditation

results.title: Ray Charles: soul of the Holy Land
results.brief_description: Lost documentary concert footage of the great Ray Charles shot during a tour to Tel Aviv and historic religious sites in 1973. Not uncovered until 30 years after being filmed, Ray and his big band (also featuring some awesome back-up singers the “Raylettes”) give a great performance of blues, soul and even a couple of Beatles tunes. Segments of the concerts are intercut with footage of Ray visiting religious sites and mixing with the locals. Note that some of the film is a bit scratchy due to the archival nature of footage. Tracks include “Let the good times roll”, “Yesterday”, “Shake” and “I can’t stop loving you”.

results.title: Raw material
results.creator_credit: Julian Biggs, Grant McLean and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Red Barker is being released from prison, but he desperately needs more than the $40 and the new suit of clothing which he is given as he leaves; he needs friendship. As it follows his experiences the film shows how the John Howard Society helps him to ward off loneliness and make a new start with his wife.

results.title: Ravel
results.creator_credit: Larry Weinstein, Julia Sereny and Niv Fichman
results.brief_description: Ravel pays homage to the great French composer Maurice Ravel. Many of Ravel’s foremost interpreters - Charles Dutoit and the Montreal Symphony Orchestra, Alicia de Larrocha, Victoria de Los Angeles, Jean-Phillipe Collard, Augustin Dumay and others, capture the sensuality, the sweetness and the power of the entire spectrum of Ravel’s work. In addition, a rare home movie footage, photographs, interviews and Ravel’s unpublished letters give the film deep insight into the composer’s elusive life.
